title: 115_hr51
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act is titled "Funding for Student Scholarships for the 1890s Land-Grant African-American Colleges and Universities Act". Congress acknowledges the establishment of 19 public African-American land-grant colleges and universities through the Act of August 30, 1890. Funding for agricultural education, research, and extension at 1890s Land-Grant African-American colleges and universities is authorized to be appropriated to the Department of Agriculture with each farm bill, enacted approximately every 5 years. The Agricultural Act of 2014 authorizes the appropriation of Federal funds for research. The Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2016 allocated $19,000,000 for education grants at 1890s Land-Grant African-American colleges and universities to increase the number of young African-Americans pursuing careers in food and agricultural sciences, including agribusiness, food production, energy, and farming. Scholarship funding is provided to increase young African-Americans pursuing careers in food and agricultural sciences, including agribusiness, food production, energy, renewable fuels, and farming marketing. The average age of farmers in the US is 60 and rising. Beginning farmers and ranchers require more assistance in financing. The Act aims to address the aging farmer population crisis in the US and increase young African-Americans pursuing careers in food and agricultural sciences. It also aims to reduce the average age of farmers and provide assistance to beginning farmers in financing. The Act aims to address the aging farmer population crisis in the US by providing assistance to beginning farmers and ranchers, reducing the average age of farmers, and offering scholarships to 1890 land-grant students in food and agricultural sciences. The Act aims to address the aging farmer population crisis in the US by providing assistance to beginning farmers and ranchers, reducing the average age of farmers, and offering scholarships to students at 1890 land-grant colleges, including Tuskegee University. The Secretary will establish a grant program to award scholarships to individuals seeking to attend eligible colleges for pursuing careers in food and agricultural sciences. $19,000,000 will be available annually from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for this purpose. The Secretary will allocate $19,000,000 annually from 2018 to 2022 for a grant program to award scholarships to individuals attending eligible colleges for careers in food and agricultural sciences, with each institution receiving $1,000,000.
